ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: CPLT 536 is a graduate-level, comparative literature course that uses Franz Kafkas oeuvre as a starting point to understanding both his work and similar authors. The most important question of the course was, What makes Kafkas imaginary so powerful that so many other authors have been inspired by him?I would recommend the course, because I learned whatI wanted to learn: about Kafka and surrounding others, and because I learned things I didnt expect.
I would recommend the course to any student interested in 20th century culture. It is much more than literature.
A unconventional approach to teaching Kafka and his influence on other writers and artists - I would highly recommend it as I never learned more about Kafka in any other course about him.
I would recommend the course. Please see my answer above.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I didnt know much about Comparative Literature and am not a graduate student in literature or the arts it helped me understand the field better. I was very uncomfortable in the course for much of the time, because I didnt know nearly as much as the other students, but I believe I learned as much as anyone else, but my starting point was a bit further back.

Thanks to this course I became acquaitned with many new literary and theoretical writers and improved my skills in linking different texts and traditions. Also, I found the discussions in class very inspiring and I feel now more encouraged to take part in them in the future.
